title: Physiologic and other effects and compliance with long-term respirator use among medical intensive care unit nurses
text:
Future studies should also examine other factors that may help increase health care personnel tolerance of long-term N95 usage
 Noncompliance with N95 use can put staff at risk from infection, a factor believed to be associated with the high rate of severe acute respiratory syndrome among health care personnel
authors: Rebmann, Terri; Carrico, Ruth; Wang, Jing

title: Health care workers' perceptions of respiratory and gastrointestinal algorithms for patient management in emergency care settings
text: Health care workers' perceptions of respiratory and gastrointestinal algorithms for patient management in emergency care settings Patients presenting with respiratory or gastrointestinal illness in emergency care settings are often not yet diagnosed but are potentially capable of transmitting disease
authors: Siow, Serena; Bryce, Elizabeth A.; Scharf, Sydney

title: The individual, environmental, and organizational factors that influence nurses' use of facial protection to prevent occupational transmission of communicable respiratory illness in acute care hospitals
text:
The individual, environmental, and organizational factors that influence nurses' use of facial protection to prevent occupational transmission of communicable respiratory illness in acute care hospitals Background: Communicable respiratory illness is an important cause of morbidity among nurses
 Communicable respiratory illness is an important cause of morbidity among health care workers each year
 One qualitative study found that media coverage of HIV and hepatitis B was an important factor in health care workers' compliance with universal precautions
authors: Nichol, Kathryn; Bigelow, Philip; O'Brien-Pallas, Linda; McGeer, Allison; Manno, Mike; Holness, D. Linn

title: Evaluation of the rationale for concurrent use of N95 filtering facepiece respirators with loose-fitting powered air-purifying respirators during aerosol-generating medical procedures
text: Published reports from the health care environment suggest that PAPRs alone offer sufficiently high levels of respiratory protection during aerosolizing medical procedures

title: Protecting health care workers from SARS and other respiratory pathogens: Organizational and individual factors that affect adherence to infection control guidelines
text: The lessons learned from SARS should be used to improve occupational health and safety for health care workers for current nosocomially transmitted infections, as well as for future potential emerging diseases
authors: Moore, David; Gamage, Bruce; Bryce, Elizabeth; Copes, Ray; Yassi, Annalee; other members of The BC Interdisciplinary Respiratory Protection Study Group,
